title: Grateful Dead Live at Saratoga Performing Arts Center on 1988-06-28
description:
Disk 1
1. tuning
2. Hell in a Bucket
3. Bertha
4. Walkin' Blues
5. Candyman
6. When I Paint My Masterpiece
7. Row Jimmy
8. Victim or the Crime
9. Foolish Heart

Disk 2
1. Scarlet Begonias
2. Fire on the Mountain
3. Estimated Prophet
4. Crazy Fingers
5. drums

Disk 3
1. space
2. I Will Take You Home
3. Goin' Down the Road Feeling Bad
4. I Need a Miracle
5. Stella Blue
6. Not Fade Away
7. Knockin' on Heaven's Door (encore)

reviews.review_text: theres nothing you can hold for very long... this version of Stella Blue is epic!!! The ending gives me goosebumps everytime. Brent and jerry create this rolling sequence of notes thats monumental and the whole band turns it in a monster sounding ending..... just incredible.... i hear trumpets, flutes, drums, stars twinkling, horses thundering, cannons shooting, just amazing....

GD's final show at SPAC very memorable sound A
performance A

High-energy, well-played show with an absolutely  blistering second set.

Scarlet-> Fire is on the same level as the revered Hampton 3.27 version, and imo Fire may even be better here.

and everything he said below re: Stella.

Last SPAC Show - Very Sweet SPAC 85 was my first show so the place has a special place in my heart. Such a great venue to see the Dead, and it drew a great crowd including many hot, young women. I was at this show and listening to it now, of course, brings back fond memories. Bertha to Row Jimmy is very well played. Victim and Foolish Heart were new songs then. I remember the Scarlet-Fire being huge. Anyways, it's too bad that there aren't any good audience recordings up of this show and the five soundboards all sound the same and you can barely hear the audience. For example, during the incredible Candyman it began to rain hard. As a result, some people broke through the security guards into shelter on the raised balcony. This streaming of heads past security guards, plain for thousands to see, combined with the heavy rainfall combined with Garcia's blistering solo caused a huge roar to erupt from the crowd. But you can barely hear it on these boards. This is one of the rare occasions when my audience recording I got in the early 90s on cassette is better than anything here. So, in short, to appreciate this show, one with a very vocal audience, you need to find a good audience recording. Jerry's solo in Row Jimmy, by the way, is very tasty. Enjoy.

Victim>Foolish A straight ahead 'Victim' into > 'Foolish' more than anything is what I remember from this show. I was completely taken in by these two songs. And however dark 'Victim' felt to me 'Foolish' was 3 times lighter.
Foolish Heart-There is some nice Piano work by Brent around 6 minutes in which extends the song out and shows just how opened ended this tune could get.
Jerry still working out the lyrics but to me this is the strongest Foolish Heart to date.
